lessonOverview.title: Unit 1 - Lesson 2
structures: A: Has he/she got a ball?
B: Yes, he/she has. / No, he/she hasn’t.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six toys (ball, bat, football, skateboard, scooter, yo-yo) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show toy flashcards. Say the word. Ask: “Where’s the scooter?” Students point in SB.
stretchStrategies: ❝Toy Detective❞ – Describe a classmate with toy vocabulary: “He’s got a skateboard.” Students guess who it is. Then, students take turns describing classmates using “has got” sentences.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say simple statements about possessions using "He's/She's got a.../He/She hasn't got a..." and ask and answer simple questions using "Has he/she got a...?" with responses like "Yes, he/she has." / "No, he/she hasn't."
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Show a picture of a child. Ask: “Has he got a yo-yo?” Students answer: “Yes, he has.” or “No, he hasn’t.”
stretchStrategies: ❝Toy Detective❞ – Describe a classmate with toy vocabulary: “He’s got a skateboard.” Students guess who it is. Then, students take turns describing classmates using “has got” sentences.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say statements using the target structure “He's/She's got a ___.” / “He/She hasn't got a ___.” and ask and answer questions using the target structure "Has he/she got a ___?" / "Yes, he/she has." / "No, he/she hasn't." to talk about possessions.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write 3 example pairs on the board: “She’s got a ball.” / “He hasn’t got a scooter.” Students make their own using SB visuals.
stretchStrategies: ❝Toy Detective❞ – Describe a classmate with toy vocabulary: “He’s got a skateboard.” Students guess who it is. Then, students take turns describing classmates using “has got” sentences.

items: Certain common holiday activities are less likely to overlap with those of Western kids (eating seafood at the beach, going on tours in large groups)
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
